snippet: The state clearly gets better results with local, community-based rehabilitation programs than incarceration.
abstract: Editorial commends strides Texas has made in reforming its juvenile justice system following public outcry in 2007 over disclosures of neglect and abuse; contends that key element of success has been reduced use of state prisons for juvenile offenders and increased reliance on local rehabilitation programs; expresses hope that data reflecting Texas's successes will aid it and other states in improving treatment of young criminals.
lead_paragraph: The state clearly gets better results with local, community-based rehabilitation programs than incarceration.
